advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Adopt a little gifted"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert says:<br><br> <font color="#666666">The new ASC8000-6 single board computer is packed with ultra-high technology: Z80 double density computer, up to 2048Kb of high speed RAM, Floppy-disk and Winchester Hard Disk controllers, DMA, up to 6 serial / 2 parallel I/O, optional 32 bit floating point processor... All on one board, fully socketed, fully documented, reliable and maintainable...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD (DEC. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice the (rare!) DMX80 printer, the two floppy drive units and SDX FDD interface.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"TO8D, the smart present"<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Yoann Riou for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BRAZILIAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.museo8bits.com" target="_blank">www.museo8bits.com</a> for this advert</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (DEC. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Christmas accounts" <br><br> "Casio, it counts"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> CLOSE-UP</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Christian Hart for this scan</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (FEB. 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Educatel advert for their correspondance courses using the Microlab system.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Your computing teacher at home !"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> IN SCHOOLS #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Laser 3000. For 5980F, play the double compatibility !"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert says:<br><br> <font color ="#666666">The Altos ACS8000-6 series. It's a barrier breaker in every sense. Our entry level, single-user, hard-disk system with floppy backup is priced under $10,000...<br> ... With MP/M at the helm, your Altos system can support up to four simulteneous users with 48 KB RAM each plus 58 MB of Winchester storage and 4 MB of floppy backup. And that adds up to the first microcomputer to give you the power and performance of a minicomputer.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 5500 ADVERT (JAN. 1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a french advert for the ISTC 5500 published in january 1981. Its is exactly the same advert used for the model 5000, apart some modification in the description (disk drive capacity). Even the picture is still the same, with a "5" added with a pen, by hand !!!</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT (1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.pugly.juice.or.jp/pugly/oldpc/" target="_blank">Pugly's web site</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>The display says: "Personal computer Pravetz 82"<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Bojidar Stefanov</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DEMO TAPE INLAY #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.primo.homeserver.hu/" target="_blank">PRIMO home-page</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MOTOROLA AD.</strong></font><br><blockquote>In fact, this advert didn't promote the Macintosh II computer but the 68020 microprocessor.<br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> ...While Apple's choice of the MC 68020 was a smart move, there's no licence on genius: the 68020 is the microprocessor of choice in advanced business system design by such industry leaders as Altos, Alpha Micro, Casio, C.Itoh, Fujitsu, Honneywell Bull, NEC, NCR, Olivetti, Plexus, Ricoh, Sanyo, Sharp, TI, Toshiba and Unisys...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Christian Hart for this scan</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, JULY 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote>Nice advert, although a little excessive.<p class="petitgris">Byte Magazine</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GENEVA AD, OCT. 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.description:
Originally starting life as "Project Reality" the Nintendo 64 was the follow up to the SNES. The press went wild over the new console, with articles claiming it could generate graphics on a par with high end Silicon Graphics workstations.
Two arcade games (Cruis'n USA and Killer Instinct) were made in 1994 to show the public what the Ultra 64, as it was now known, would be capable of. The announcement on the Killer Instinct intro "available for your home in 1995, own a Nintendo Ultra 64!" may have seemed like good publicity, but was a bit misleading. The N64 wasn't released until 1996, and the change of name to Nintendo 64 meant nobody could buy an Ultra 64 even if they wanted one. To make matters worse, both games used different hardware, not only from that of the N64 but each other as well!
By the time the N64 launched it could only ever be a victim of its own hype. The CD-ROM was rapidly becoming the favoured format for consoles, mainly due to the increased storage space and lower production costs, and Nintendo's decision to stick with cartridges would prove costly. The limited storage size of cartridges, coupled with a tiny 4 KB limit on texture size, meant the N64 could never live up to the stunning rendered images that had been printed in the press.
The machine received a number of great games, most notably GoldenEye and the classic launch title Super Mario 64, but this simply wasn't enough. Third party publishers abandoned the N64 in favour of the PlayStation and the releases started to dry up, with very few games being released towards the end of the console's lifespan.
In December 1999 the 64DD was released in Japan. First announced in 1995, before the N64 was even launched, most people were expecting a CD based add-on. Instead it used magnetic disks, similar to those used in Zip drives. Although the disks were cheaper to produce they had the same 64 MB maximum size as the cartridges, rendering the whole idea somewhat pointless. Like most console add-ons of this type, the 64DD was largely considered to be a failure. Only nine pieces of software were ever released for the 64DD and the machine's world-wide launch was cancelled.

emulator.description: The best Nintendo 64 emulator around. Excellent compatibility
emulator.name: Project64

computer.name: Nintendo 64
computer.peripherals: Controller Pak, Rumble Pak, 4 MB Expansion Pak, 64DD
computer.ram: 4 MB RDRAM, upgradable to 8 MB with the Expansion Pak
